model_response: Excellent choice! HRQoL is a strong candidate for the primary outcome measure.  What elements of HRQoL should we assess?

Yes, the EQ-5D-5L is a generic self-reported health status measure that provides a descriptive system for health states. Each dimension in the EQ-5D health states corresponds to a pair of levels of health states. Each level in the pair is given a descriptive term, a corresponding level on the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and a level on the Quality Adjectives scale. The EQ-5D is derived from five dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain or discomfort, and anxiety or depression. Each dimension has 3 levels of health, which can be scored on a 0-1 scale, resulting in a total of 243 different EQ-5D health states. In this questionnaire, the EQ-5D level for mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain or discomfort, and anxiety or depression are each scored on a 100 mm visual analog scale (VAS). The level for the last two dimensions is expressed as a 3-point multi-dimensional visual analog scale (with endpoints labeled "no problems", "some/mild problems," and "extreme problems"), resulting in 243 health states, each described by both a one-dimensional level on the VAS and a two-dimensional level on the 3-point Mobility and Self-Care/Usual Activities VAS. The Health States UtilitiesSF 36 Mark 2® questionnaire (Q1 to Q5) is also included to elicit information on the extent to which the dimensions of the EQ-5D Health States are reflected in the 3 summary domains of the SF-36 Questionnaire.  You can find more information about the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire at [URL].

I would like to also assess the European organ-based quality of life (QOL) instrument (EORTC QOL Group), a specialized tool for ovarian cancer. It includes a disease-specific module for ovarian patient with questions covering symptoms, physical and emotional functioning, and work and social life. Also, the FACT-G measure is a good tool for evaluating the effects of supportive care. It's a brief instrument that assesses psychological well-being. It can be self-reported or proxy-reported by caregivers. It covers 15 domains with items ranging from physical pain to emotional well-being. model_response: We can assess the subjective sleep quality the night before surgery, which is when the esketamine infusion is administered. This timing will demonstrate whether the esketamine is having an immediate effect on sleep quality.

Excellent idea. For assessing subjective sleep quality before and after surgery, we can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which is a standardized self-report measure of the presence and severity of insomnia symptoms. This instrument consists of 19 items rated on a scale of 0–3, with a total score ranging from 0 to 54. A score of 0–10 is considered normal, 11–16 is mild, 17–21 borderline, and >22 is severe sleep disturbances. The responses are categorized and summed for four problematic sleep domains: sleep latency, sleep duration, non-refreshing sleep, and daytime dysfunction. Higher PSQI total scores indicate a greater severity of sleep disturbances.

Objective sleep quality measures can be obtained through polysomnography in a sleep laboratory, but these are resource expensive and not feasible for use in a clinical setting. However, home polysomnography can be used in select cases. To assess the relationship between oxygen saturation and the apnea- hypopnea index can be useful for establishing a baseline. In patients with sleep apnea, however, use of CPAP prior to surgery may affect the results. 24-hour Holter monitoring may be helpful to assess sleep fragmentation by providing an overview of sleep patterns during a 24-hour period. The number of significant sleep episodes, disturbances in heart rate variability, and other measures of heart rate variability have been used to measure sleep quality. However, currently there are not established standard measures for this. 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring can also provide insights into the nocturnal hypertensive episodes which could be related to obstructive sleep apnea. 23 However, the most feasible and widely used objective measure of sleep quality may be home polysomnography. This is a portable sleep laboratory performed by experienced sleep technicians in the patient's home. The patient performs an evening polysomnogram and a split-night polysomnogram on the night before surgery. The split-night polysomnogram is important, because it correlates the patient's sleep apnea with pulmonary and cardiovascular parameters. The portable sleep laboratory allows one to diagnose sleep apnea objectively and establish a baseline index of severity for this condition. In addition, the use of portable sleep laboratory may help to optimize treatment by adjusting the patient's oxygen saturation and, thus, improve the outcome by decreasing the incidence of adverse cardiovascular and pulmonary events. 24 This may also help to stratify the patients according to risk in planning further treatment.

To accurately assess objective sleep quality, I recommend measuring them before the surgery, on the night before surgery, and on the first night after surgery. This will allow us to track changes in sleep parameters before and after the intervention.
The McGill Pain Questionnaire is a reliable and valid tool for assessing pain intensity. We could use it to capture pain intensity before, during, and after the intervention in our study.
We should assess the pain intensity on the preoperative evening and the morning of surgery.

To assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days post-surgery, we can use the Quality of Recovery scale, which is a 7-item scale assessing sleep quality, depression, anxiety, and energy and vitality. This scale has a total possible score range of 21-108, with higher scores indicating poorer sleep quality.

It would be ideal to assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days post-surgery on an outpatient basis or during a routine office visit. This is important because patients may not have realized any sleeping problems before surgery and might not recall any sleep problems 30 days post-surgery, thus highlighting the importance of obtaining patient feedback about their pre-existing sleep quality before surgery.

Some key considerations include: • Representativeness of the measure: The measure chosen should accurately reflect the change in the outcome of interest following the intervention. • Reliability and validity: The measure should be reliable and well-validated for the outcome to be assessed. • Measurement burden: The measure should be easily obtainable, cost-effective, and not overly burdensome for patients to complete. • Comparability and standardization: The measure should ideally be externally standardized and be comparable across studies and overtime. • Criterion-based and criterion-relevant: The measure should be clearly linked to the established outcome(s) of interest. • Appropriate duration and timing: The measure should ideally be assessed at the appropriate time point relative to the intervention. model_response: Secondary outcome measures are those that are related to the study's primary outcome measure, but not as critical as the primary measure. In a clinical trial assessing the safety and effectiveness of a new sunscreen, secondary outcome measures may include assessments of side effects, skin irritation, and the time required to reapply the sunscreen after water exposure. Do you have any ideas for secondary outcome measures that would be relevant to your study?

The water resistance measure is an indication of how well the sunscreen resists water. It can be measured using a standard test developed by the United States' Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The standard test involves submerging the sunscreen in water for a period of 80 minutes, and then checking its UV protection. The sunscreen is considered water-resistant if it continues to provide adequate UV protection after 80 minutes of water immersion. The Fitzpatrick scale is a five-point scale used to classify skin types according to their response to sun exposure. It helps determine the proper amount of sun protection needed for different skin types. The Dermatological disorders measure is used to ensure that participants have no skin conditions that could impact the study results. Photosensitizing agents are substances that can interact with sunlight to cause skin reactions. These include medications like some antibiotics, sulfa drugs, some over-the-counter antihistamines, and some antidepressants. Patients taking these medications may need exclusion from this study.

model_response: Excellent question. In addition to the 13-item Caregiver Strain Index, I would recommend exploring the use of the following measures: The Zarit Burden Interview The Zarit Burden Interview is a multiple-item instrument that assesses the caregiver's perceptions of the effects of caregiving and the level of burden associated with it. It includes 19 items and has good reliability and validity. It assesses four domains of role burden: Physical impact Emotional impact Dependency impact Economic impact Social/work impact Scores range from 19 to 55, with higher scores reflecting higher burden.  The depression module of the CARE-OAR measure The Chinese version of the depression module of the CARE-OAR measure has been adapted and validated [49]. The CARE-OAR measure is a comprehensive assessment tool that includes the following subscales: Care recipient burden, caregiver burden, reassessment/trial outcome appraisal, and psychological impact of assessment. The care receiver module has been adapted for use with family caregivers caring for people at the end of life. The instrument can also be used in the assessment of burden of disease or assessment-related burden. The inter-item reliability of the Chinese adaptation of the depression module (C-CARE-D) is adequate to good. The validity of the C-CARE-D has been well supported in a sample of Chinese caregivers of people with chronic illness.  Mental and physical scales of the Multidimensional Assessment of Psychological Support for Primary Caregivers for the Terminally Ill (MAPS-PCTI) The Chinese version of the MAPS-PCTI has been adapted and validated.  The MAPS-PCTI is a 33-item scale for assessing the physical and mental burden of family caregivers caring for a family member or close friend at the end of life. The assessment includes demographic data, care recipient characteristics and health status, caregiver burden, and care recipient prognosis and preferences, and outcomes for the caregiver and care recipient. Exploring the use of these measures will provide you with a more comprehensive picture

In addition to assessing caregiver burden and mental health, it is important to evaluate the intervention's impact on caregivers' perceptions of the patient's quality of life. One measure you can include is the World Health Organization Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF) assessment. This tool provides a score between 0 and 100, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. It includes 18 items across four domains: physical health, psychological health, environment, and social relationships. Measuring this outcome at baseline and follow-up assessments can help evaluate the intervention's influence on patient quality of life.

Yes, it would also be useful to assess other areas of caregiver burden, such as physical and mental well-being. The Short-Form 36 (SF-36) survey would quantify these domains. The Chinese version of the SF-36 has been used in previous studies of caregivers of cancer patients and has good internal consistency and test-retest reliability. Measures of positive and negative affectivity using the Chinese Brief Five-Item Personality Inventory would also help to determine the program's impact on caregivers' affective states. Other measures of health status and general well-being, such as the self-rated health item from the SF-36, could provide additional information on the impact of the intervention.  Finally, you may also want to consider measuring quality of life. The Chinese version of the EQ-5D-5L instrument is a standardized preference-based measure of health-related quality of life that can also be used to measure the impact of interventions.

Another important consideration is the care recipients' functional status and quality of life. These measures will help determine the impact of the intervention on the care recipients' condition. A commonly used outcome measure for functional status is the 12-item version of the Short Form-36 (SF-12). This measure assesses the physical and mental health of the care recipient and provides score ranges from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate better function. Another measure that assesses the care recipient's quality of life is the Manoff Quality of Life Questionnaire. This measure has 16 questions that cover six areas: mood, communication, motor skills, sensory perception, self-care, and bowel and bladder. Scores are converted to a total score, which can range from 47 to 168, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. Measuring these outcomes at baseline, Week 6, and Week 8 will help you determine the intervention's impact on the care recipients' health and well-being.  [END]

Yes, that's right. Together, these measure the right range  of outcomes and provide a comprehensive evaluation of the intervention's effects on caregivers' burden and well-being. Sure, measure descriptions and time frames for these secondary outcome measures are as follows:
1. Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced: Patients will be asked to fill out a sports participation diary to record the number of sport units (eg, soccer, basketball, swimming) per week and the total amount of time spent on sports per week during the 12 months before surgery and after surgery (0, 6, 12, 24 and 36 months).
2. Length of surgery in minutes: Surgeons will measure the length of surgery as the time between anesthesia administration and achieving hemostasis at the end of surgery (0, 6, 12, and 24 months).
3. Subjective change of instability: Patients will be asked to grade the severity of their symptoms from 0 (no pain/instability) to 10 (worst possible symptoms) on a 10-cm visual analog scale at 0, 6, 12, and 24 months.
4. Patient satisfaction: Patients will be asked to fill out a satisfaction questionnaire at 0, 6, 12, and 24 months which includes questions on the success of the surgery, quality of life, physical activity, and cosmetic results.
5. Return to sports: Patients will be asked to describe their level and variety of sports activity at regular intervals postoperatively (0, 6, 12, and 24 months).
6. Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced: This measure will be the same as measure 1 however, time frames will be reported at 6, 12, and 24 months.

8. Subjective change of instability: This measure will be the same as measure 3, however, time frames will be reported at 6, 12, and 24 months.

What are the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the study subjects? What are the inclusion criteria? Exclusion criteria?  Any subject may be eligible if met with the exclusion criteria and if the following criteria are met:
Males and females as either can be treated.
Age of the subject between 18 to 70 years.
Subjects in the non-cardiac and non-vascular surgery unit.
Provides written informed consent
Not on medication known to affect bleeding or clotting.
No major surgical or general medical disease.
A negative test of PT, aPTT, bleeding time in the normal or within the therapeutic range. No signs of DIC or hypercoagulable state. No clinically significant disorder that may alter coagulation or bleeding. No history of thrombosis or thromboembolism. No signs of major gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract bleeding disorder. No history of cancer or use of medication known to increase risk of bleeding. No significant use of drugs or medication that may affect bleeding or clotting, the use of hematinic vitamins, anticoagulation, or antiplatelet. No use of anticoagulants or anti platelet such as OAC, P2Y 12 inhibitor, or anti-coagulant within 21 days prior to the day of surgery. No clinical investigation or screening for POD in the past 30 days. No history of bleeding or thrombosis of the intravenous umbilical vein for the placement of central line in the past 28 days.
Exclusion criteria are as follows:
History of bleeding condition.
Patient with hypersplenism.
Significant renal dysfunction.
History of thrombosis or bleeding disorders.
History of allergy to TXA drugs or device.
Pregnancy, nursing, or breast-feeding.
Life-threatening illnesses that may affect results of the study.

model_response: This is an important measure because it will assess the safety of the Q2W and Q4W dosing of Itepekibma in COPD patients.

Secondary outcome measures include the COPD worsening metric, and the change from baseline in health-related quality of life (HRQL), dyspnoea, COPD-related symptoms, and adverse events. They will be assessed from baseline up to Week 72.

The secondary outcome measures will help assess the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and safety / tolerability of Itepekimab in participants with COPD. The time to first AECOPD is a measure of disease progression. The change from baseline in FEV1 and SGRQ total score indicate the impact of the drug on lung function and disease severity. The change from baseline in EQ-5D-5L index score reflects overall quality of life and health-related utility. The change from baseline in EQ-VAS reflects the change in perceived health-related quality of life.

Certainly! The EQ-5D-5L single index score reflects the quality of the participant's health status and well-being. The EQ-VAS assesses the participant's perception of their health over time. The SGRQ is a tool used to measure the burden and impact of breathing difficulties on participants' daily life and wellbeing.

model_response: Great! Now, let's move on to the secondary outcome measures. Any suggestions on the secondary outcome measures?

That's a great idea! Measuring comfort behaviors could provide important supplementary information about patients' comfort levels. We could use the Comfort Behavior Rating Scale to assess comfort behaviors. This scale is designed to assess patients' self-initiated comfort behaviors and how they respond to unpleasant stimuli, such as pain, distress, and discomfort. It consists of 18 items that describe patients' actions such as repositioning, touching, crying, and oral and digital exploration. With a 5-point Likert scale, it can provide a reliable and valid measure of patients' comfort behaviors.

Great! The Comfort Behaviors Checklist with numerical scoring for pain and comfort would be a valuable addition to our study. It would provide a more comprehensive picture of the comfort level of ICU patients. Let's include this measure as a secondary outcome.

A good idea. Sleep quality is an important aspect of comfort, and it may be affected by the nursing intervention. We can use the Sleep Quality Instrument to assess sleep quality. However, we would have to exclude patients who are on continuous mechanical ventilation from the study because they won't be able to complete the survey. Do you agree?

Great choice! The General Comfort Scale, the General Comfort Scale Short Form, and the General Comfort Scale Questionnaire all measure the general comfort level of ICU patients. The General Comfort Scale is the most popular measure of this type. It consists of 13 items that are scored on a visual analog scale from 0 to 10. The General Comfort Scale Short Form has the same items but is scored on a scale from 0 to 2. The General Comfort Scale Questionnaire is a longer 28-item measure that can be used to assess the general comfort of patients with chronic lung disease. The General Comfort Scale is useful for measuring general comfort as well as assessing the effectiveness of nursing interventions. All of these measures are widely used and easy to administer, making them useful for research as well as clinical practice.

The study instrument for hearing-related outcomes could consist of a questionnaire to determine demographic information, medical history, and family history. The Speech-in-Noise Test (SIN), pure-tone audiometry, and the Tympanometry could also be administered to evaluate hearing acuity.

I also suggest considering the following measures:
2. Speech-in-noise tests: This test assesses hearing in noisier environments and can help monitor changes in hearing over time in children with a genetic predisposition to hearing loss. 
3. Pure-tone average (psychoacoustic) thresholds: These measures the average hearing thresholds at different frequencies for the better and worse hearing ears. It can show changes in hearing sensitivity over time that are not apparent at a single listening level. 
4. Middle-ear ossicle-transfer function and distortion-product otoacoustic emissions: These measures can help determine how well the middle ear is functioning and show changes that may indicate the presence or progression of the disease. 
5. Speech-discrimination in noisy-background tests: This test assesses a child’s ability to understand speech in noisy environments, which can provide important information on the presence or severity of hearing loss. 
What are some challenges you could foresee during data collection or management?

One other measure I'd recommend is pure-tone audiometry thresholds. Pure-tone audiometry thresholds provide information about the sensitivity of the auditory system to sound. Pure-tone audiometry thresholds can help assess changes in hearing sensitivity over time, detect the presence of hearing loss in a participants with gene-related hearing loss, and determine the extent of hearing loss. We can measure pure-tone audiometry thresholds at baseline and annual follow-up visits for 4 years.

It's important to include an assessment of sentence intelligibility as an outcome measure. Sentence intelligibility is a measure of the ability to understand speech in challenging listening environments such as noisy restaurants and crowded family gatherings. It's important to monitor changes in sentence intelligibility to detect potential speech processing difficulties early, such as those due to cochlear implant overheating or hearing loss. We can measure sentence intelligibility annually for 4 years as well.

I would recommend including quality-of-life measures as a secondary outcome measure. Hearing loss and genetic conditions can have a significant impact on a child's quality of life, and it's important to monitor changes in pediatric participants' well-being over time. Measures of well-being could include questionnaires such as the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory or the Achenbach Burkhart Childhood Hearing Loss Quality-of-Life Questionnaire. We can assess these measures every 6 months for 4 years.

model_response: Another suggested primary outcome measure is cost-utility data. This measure will evaluate the costs and benefits of the intervention compared to the control group. We can measure costs by collecting data on health care resources used and the costs of medications, hospital stays, and other expenses. Benefits will be measured in terms of improved quality of life, which can be assessed using standardized questionnaires. This outcome measure might be especially important if the intervention is not yet widely available or is associated with a high cost to participants or the healthcare system. You're right. We really need to consider the cost-utility of the intervention.

Other primary outcome measures could include length of hospital stay and quality of life metrics. Length of hospital stay could help us evaluate the impact of decannulation on overall healthcare costs, while quality of life metrics such as the Short Form 36-Item Health Survey (SF-36) can help us assess the patient's satisfaction with the decannulation process. However, these metrics should be assessed only after the required post-decannulation follow-up period to ensure accurate representation of the patient's long-term health outcomes.
Wonderful! Let's talk about secondary outcome measures too. What are some examples of secondary measures that could be incorporated into this study?
Definitely. So with those outcome measures in place, we can collect a lot of important data and help improve the decannulation process for patients with prolonged tracheostomies.
Secondary outcome measures could include the length of tracheostomy, patient respiratory status with the tracheostomy in place, and need for mechanical ventilation.

Another important second outcome measure could be quality of life before and after decannulation. This measure will assess the impact of decannulation on patients' quality of life using different scales, such as the Nottingham Quality of Life measure. The measure will help us understand the effect of decannulation on patients' social, psychological, and physical well-being.

Another outcome measure could be patient-reported outcomes after decannulation. This measure will assess patients' perspectives of the overall process and outcome of decannulation. For example, we can ask patients about their experience with the decannulation process, their satisfaction with the procedure, and their perceived benefit of decannulation. We can collect this data 2 weeks, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.
So, when considering our proposed protocol, which outcome measures would you include?

The primary outcome measure we will use is the number of days until decannulation. We will also include short-term complication rates: number of days to reintubation, number of patients decannulated to tracheostomy due to complications, and number of patients with permanent tracheostomy. To identify prognostic factors, we will collect demographic information, medical history, and clinical characteristics: age, etiology of tracheostomy, comorbidities, and GCS. To assess patient satisfaction and quality of life, we will use the Harvard Medical Satisfaction Questionnaire and the Impact of Tracheostomy (ITS) measure.

Couldn't find a better home for this question in another board, so I'm posting here. 

Is there a reason to mask ventilation with a mask in pulmonary function tests (spirometry)?

Isn't the purpose of such tests to measure lung function, without any interference from mouth breathing or nasal breathing?

Edit: I understand the importance of mask breathing for spirometry, when measuring flows and pressures in non cooperative people (e.g. toddlers, people with cognitive impairments). I was mainly pointing out the importance of unmasked spirometry as a gold standard test of lung function.
In patients with poorly controlled asthma, mouth breathing during spirometry might interfere with the measurement of FEV1 and similar lung function parameters, as the mouth-to-mouth leak is ~100% on expiration (see here) and might lead to an overestimation of FEV1.

model_response: I would also recommend assessing the Area Under the Curve (AUC), a measure of the total amount of drug in the body over time.

To assess drug absorption, we can measure the area under the curve (AUC0-t), which will show us the total amount of drug administered up to a certain time point. By comparing the AUC0-t between the groups, we'll know how well the drug is absorbed and eliminated from the body. This measure can help us identify potential drug-drug interactions and potential adverse effects on the liver and other organs.

Secondary outcome measures could include changes in weight, vital signs, physical exam findings, and laboratory values, such as liver function tests and coagulation parameters. These measures will help us assess for any potential adverse effects of the drugs, such as liver toxicity or bleeding.

The criteria for inclusion in the study will be patients with acute complicated or chronic recurrent left-sided sigmoid diverticulitis. The criteria for exclusion from the study will be other types of diverticulitis or colonic disease.
Great, could you explain the sample size estimation for the study?
The study will enroll 200 participants.
Excellent idea! I also think the secondary outcome measures are very important. Does anything come to mind?
Great, now we can move on to the secondary outcome measures. Could you briefly describe the secondary outcome measures and the time frame for assessing them?

I'd recommend including the EQ-5D-5L as a secondary outcome measure, along with the Short Inflammatory Bowel Disease Questionnaire (IBDQ). These measures capture different aspects of disease burden and health-related quality of life. The EQ-5D-5L is a generic measure that can be used in a variety of conditions, while the IBDQ is specifically adapted for patients with IBD.  Other secondary measures could include the EuroQol 6-dimension questionnaire (EQ-6D) and the Short-Form 12 Health Survey (SF-12). These are also general measures of health status that can be administered in a variety of populations, and are frequently used in clinical trials.

The SF-36 is a measure of physical and mental health. It consists of 36 questions on physical and mental health, including measures of pain, role limitation due to physical and mental health problems, social functioning, and emotional well-being. The measure has 5 sub-scales (role-specific physical and mental components) and a role physical and role emotional summary component. We will assess the SF-36 at multiple time points after the intervention to assess changes in physical and mental health. The Low Anterior Resection Syndrome (LAS) Score is a tool used to evaluate symptoms and complications of a low anterior resection which is performed in patients with a rectal cancer. The LAS Score assesses symptoms of pain, discomfort, and straining for bowel function, as well as changes in stool frequency and quality. The assessment is conducted preoperatively and three postoperative time points. We will measure changes in LAS symptoms with the measure while patients are in the hospital and six weeks, three months, and one year after the intervention. The anastomosis insufficiency, intraoperative complications, exitus, length of stay, and readmission rates will allow us to evaluate patient safety and outcomes and guide future interventions. The data on these measures will be collected prospectively during the study. The measures will be administered by the team assigned to the patient.  Would you like me to provide the measure description and timing for each measure?

Excellent! It seems like we've finalized our list of outcome measures. Do you have any suggestions for other relevant measures?

Thank you for your help in finalizing the measures for our clinical trial. I'll add the MEAQ-30 to the list of outcome measures. The final outcome measure is mindfulness. To assess this, we can use the Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ). Mindfulness has been shown to improve resilience and emotional regulation. The FFMQ can provide information on five facets of mindfulness, including present-moment awareness, non-reactive attitude to internal experiences, observing, describe inner experiences without judgment, acting with awareness, and noting. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. What do you think of using the FFMQ for assessing mindfulness?

Excellent! The IUS-12 will be our outcome measure for intolerance of uncertainty. The last outcome measure we will use is need for cognitive closure. To assess this, we can use the Cognitive Closure Scale (CCS). The CCS can help identify individuals with a tendency to seek certainty and avoid ambiguity, which can interfere with resilience. Administering this measure at the one-month mark is appropriate. What do you think about using the CCS?

Sounds good! The Brief COPE scale will be included as an outcome measure for coping. The last outcome measure we need to discuss is attachment styles. To assess attachment styles, we can use the short version of the Adult Attachment Interview (AAI). Attachment styles impact an individual's ability to form and maintain social relationships, which is important in the military context. Assessing attachment styles using the AAI will help us understand how participants form and maintain relationships. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. What are your thoughts on using the AAI as an outcome measure?

Excellent choice! The PANSE questionnaire will be included as an outcome measure for positive and negative social exchanges. The final outcome measure we will use is social functioning. To assess this, we can use the Calgary Social Support questionnaire. Social functioning relates to an individual's ability to function in daily life and is another important factor in mental health and resilience. The questionnaire will provide insight into how participants' social functioning may have improved or declined over time as a result of the intervention. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. What do you think of using the Calgary Social Support questionnaire for social functioning?

Perfect choice! The final outcome measure we will use is stress reactivity. To assess stress reactivity, we can use the Trier Social Stress Test. Stress reactivity is an important factor in mental health and well-being, and understanding how participants respond to stressors can provide valuable information. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. How does that sound?

Excellent decision! The PSQI will be included as an outcome measure for sleep. The last outcome measure is substance use. To assess changes in substance use, we can use the Timeline Follow-Back (TLFB) interview. Substance use is a common factor in mental health and well-being, and assessing changes in use over time is important for understanding participants' trajectory and response to our intervention. We can administer the TLFB at the one-month mark. What are your thoughts on using the TLFB?

Excellent decision! The Social Support Survey will be included as an outcome measure. The final outcome measure we will use is alcohol use. To assess alcohol use, we can use the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT). Alcohol use can have both positive and negative effects on mental health and resilience, and understanding participants' levels of alcohol use is important for our study. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. What are your thoughts on using the AUDIT?

Excellent choice! The RSES will be added as an outcome measure. Finally, the last measure we'll include is anger. To assess anger, we can use the Short-Form of the State Anger Scale (SAS). Assessing anger is important for understanding how anger affects mental health and resilience. We can administer this measure at the one-month mark. What are your thoughts on using the SAS as an outcome measure?

model_response: The WOMAC Questionnaire is a self-administered questionnaire that measures pain, stiffness, and disability of the knee and upper leg and thigh in adults with knee osteoarthritis. A total score can be calculated by adding the responses to the three questions in the index (0-20 with higher scores indicating more severe disease); it has good reliability and validity when used in clinical and research settings.
The time frame for assessing functional limitations using the WOMAC index should be specified as self-reported over the past week. This question should be assessed only at baseline.

Secondary outcomes would include measures of pain intensity and pain relief, assessed using the pain numeric rating scale. The measure should also include descriptions of the time frame for evaluation. Since this study involves the use of interferential therapy, it may be important to include measures of muscle strength and functionality, assessed using the timed walk test. I recommend mentioning the time frame for each of the assessments.

Sure, here are the descriptions for pain intensity and muscle strength:  *Visual Analog Scale (VAS): Participants are asked to mark a marking pen to indicate their pain level on a 10-cm linear scale, anchored by words “no pain” and “worst pain imaginable.” The measurement is taken at 0 minutes and after the intervention. *Handheld Dynamometer (dyn): Participants are asked to contract their muscles as hard as they can and the amount of force during a maximal voluntary contraction is measured in kilograms. This measurement is taken before the intervention and after the intervention.

Pain intensity can be assessed at both baseline and the end of four weeks. Muscle strength can be assessed at baseline and then again one week after the intervention. The time frame for muscle strength measurement is important to establish whether the intervention has an impact on muscle strength. Do you have any other questions?

model_response: The AUC of the drug reflects the total absorption of the drug in the body and its ability to maintain a therapeutic concentration. This measure captures the efficacy of the treatment and helps to determine the dosage regimen of the drug. The Cmax measures the maximum concentration of the drug in the body and provides an indication of the drug's efficacy at the maximum possible dose. It can help to determine if the drug's formulation can be adjusted to prolong the therapeutic effect. As the participants will be fasting, the meal effect should also be considered and measured separately. Any other relevant secondary outcomes that may influence the effect of the drug can also be considered to ensure the study is well-designed.

We can measure AUC and Cmax using both non-compartmental and compartmental methods. Non-compartmental methods are more commonly used in pharmacokinetic studies, while compartment modeling may be used for bioequivalence studies. I'll explain both methods in the next section.
The AUC and Cmax should be measured using validated methods, which may include HPLC or another appropriate test.

To ensure that we have enough data to accurately estimate the AUC and Cmax, we will need to collect at least 8 blood samples for the first dosing (i.e., 0-8 hours), 7 samples for the second dosing (i.e., 8- 8+ hours), and 6 samples for the remaining time points.

The full outcome measures for this trial are as follows: Plasma concentration of lamotrigine versus concentration of lamotrigine in another brand. Plasma concentration of lamotrigine versus time over 72 hours. model_response: Certainly. I suggest including measures for the change in the Montreal Symptom Severity Scores and quality of life assessment using the Irritable Bowel Syndrome Quality of Life (IBSQOL) questionnaire. In addition, the fecal calprotectin level might be useful to evaluate the response to treatment. Would those measures be acceptable?

The IBS-SSS is a 36-item symptom-based questionnaire designed to assess the severity of gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with IBS. The questionnaire encompasses 4 domains: stool frequency, stool form, pain or discomfort, and associated distress/bloating. Each item is scored on a 4-point Likert scale (1, rarely; 2, several times per month; 3, once a month; and 4, several times per week), and the total score ranges from 42 to 168. Higher scores indicate greater disease severity. This scale is widely used in clinical practice and research, and is a valid and reliable measure of IBS symptom severity. Another option for the primary outcome measure would be the Total Overall Symptom Score of the IBS Quality of Life Questionnaire (IBS-QOL). The IBS-QOL is a condition-specific measure that also assesses overall gastrointestinal and extra-digestive symptoms, quality of life, and mental well-being. It is made up of 11 items with response options of never/almost never (score of 0), several times per week (range 1-2), and several times per day (range 2-3). The scale does not have a total score but is calculated using a summation of the symptom items. The Total Overall Symptom Score can range from 0-22 and higher scores reflect worse outcomes. However, I am not familiar with the IBS-QOL, and more information is needed on its psychometric properties and other aspects such as the time frame for assessment.

Yes, I think a valid and relevant measure is Inflammatory Bowel Disease Questionnaire (IBDQ) that assesses the impact of IBS on the daily lives of patients. This questionnaire includes 30 items that evaluate problems such as feelings of pain or discomfort, mood, and activity limitations. A decrease in total score indicates improvement in the quality of life related to IBS. This questionnaire would be useful to evaluate the effects of faecal microbiota transplantation on the burden of illness and the patient's quality of life.

The dysbiosis index is a non-metric multidimensional scaling (nMDS) ordination-based approach, calculated from an analysis of the composition of gut microbiota. In this method, a cluster analysis is carried out on the Bray-Curtis similarities between samples and the results are visualized on two-dimensional plots, resulting in two scores for each individual that describe the degree to which the microbial communities from different bowel sites are separated. The lower the score, the greater the dissimilarity between sample microbiota groups.

Other potential secondary outcome measures might include assessing changes in quality of life, as measured by the IBS-Qual-60, and changes in fecal immunosorbent (Faecal IgA) and calprotectin.  What do you think? Would you like to make any other suggestions to improve the study protocol?

model_response:
Pharmacokinetics measure the movement of a drug in the body. The time and rate at which the drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and eliminated is important information in determining dosing, efficacy, adverse effects and toxicity of a medication. The PK (pharmacokinetic) of a drug is affected by many different factors, which include drug interactions with food and other medications, drug-drug interactions, and liver and kidney function, all of which will be evaluated to determine the safety and efficacy of the drug QL1706H for use in human clinical trials.
Measure of pharmacokinetics; a key consideration in determining dosing, efficacy, adverse effects and toxicity Minimum observed drug level After single administration
Rapidity with which a drug is absorbed.  Affinity  of  drug  for  plasma  proteins  (high  affinity  =  quickly  removed)  Volume  of  distribution  of  drug  (high  volume  =  widely  distributed)  Biological  half-life  (time  it  takes  for  half  the  initial  dose  to  be  eliminated) First-order  elimination  rate  Zero-order  elimination  rate Non-linear  input-output  curve  (sigmoidal)  -  steep  at  beginning - little  uptake  at low  doses - high  uptake  at  high  doses

Given that this measure evaluates the drug's concentration, it would be most helpful to assess this measure at the end of the dosing interval, which is the time when the drug is most likely to be at its lowest level. What would be an ideal frequency for assessing this outcome measure?

It describes the severity and impact of adverse events, allowing us to assess the safety and tolerability of the drug without relying on subjective reporting. For the safety and tolerability measure, we would need to conduct regular examinations at regular intervals throughout the trial. This would help us monitor and assess the patient's response to the drug and any potential adverse events. 4.

model_response: Sure. Arterial thickness can be assessed by measuring the thickness and stiffness of the carotid arteries. Arterial stiffness can be assessed using pulse-wave velocity, augmentation index, and augmented pulse pressure. Baroreflex sensitivity can be assessed using echocardiogram with baroreflex stimulation. Sympathetic response to stress can be assessed by measuring heart rate and blood pressure before, during, and after sympathetic stimulation using drugs or exercise. For the secondary outcomes, I would suggest adding heart rate variability and stress hormone levels to the measurement list after obtaining consent from the participants. Heart rate variability is a noninvasive test to assess the nervous system function and it can provide insight into the autonomic balance. Stress hormone levels, such as epinephrine, norepinephrine, and cortisol, can reflect the sympathetic nervous system activity. How do you think these measures would fit into your research design?

Some potential secondary outcome measures could include the blood pressure, heart rate, lipid and glucose levels, and inflammatory markers. However, it is best if you consult with experts in your field to determine the most appropriate measures for your study.

Sure, here are the details for each measure: Arterial elasticity - this measure will be assessed by Doppler ultrasound and reported as the ratio of systolic/diastolic ankle-brachial index. It will estimate microvascular function and peripheral vascular resistance. Neurovascular function - this measure will be assessed by measuring the latency and amplitude of the arterial wave reflection, and post-ischemia blood pressure wave reflection, using hand grip. Ankle-brachial index - assessed by measuring blood pressure in the lower arm and ankle with a sphygmomanometer. The resulting ratio will provide a measure of lower-limb artery stiffness. I should also ask whether you wish to include other clinical findings in your study, such as blood pressure, heart rate, heart rate variability, body temperature, and signs of inflammation. What do you think? Any additions?
[SPOC] Arterial thickness and compliance (arterial elasticity) To assess the function of vascular tissues: to identify those with increased susceptibility for formation of atherosclerotic plaques. Latency and amplitude of AWV wave reflection Non-invasive technique to evaluate microvascular resistance To measure aortic blood flow Noninvasive method to study aortic blood flow To assess limb blood flow (used at the ankle) Noninvasive way to calculate blood pressure in the lower limb Aortic stiffness parameter - a measure of central vascular resistance. Aortic stiffness is used to measure compliance of arterial structures. Increased stiffness might be an early sign of subendocardial ischemia, when the artery is withstanding increased afterload and is still capable of maintaining vascular flow.

Excellent! And finally, what about the percent change in hemoglobin levels? Is this measure needed to assess the effectiveness of the combination therapy?

Great! One important secondary outcome measure is the change in transfusion requirements. In PNH, transfusions are often required due to anemia caused by intravascular hemolysis. Monitoring changes in transfusion requirements will help us assess the impact of the combination therapy on anemia. Another important secondary outcome measure is the change in PNH-related symptoms. Patients with PNH can experience a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, shortness of breath, and gastrointestinal disturbances. By monitoring changes in PNH symptoms, we can assess the effectiveness of the combination therapy in relieving these symptoms. How do you feel about these measures, and do you have any others that you would like to add?

I agree. Another secondary outcome measure is the change in transfusion requirements, as assessed by the incremental increase in transfusions. This measure helps evaluate whether the combination therapy decreases the need for additional red blood cell (RBC) transfusion, which is a common complication of PNH. What are your thoughts on including this measure?

I agree that transfusion avoidance is a good measure to assess the impact of the combination therapy on anemia management in PNH. Would you also like to discuss the duration of the study and the number of visits per year?
Excellent! Let's continue our discussion on secondary measures. What about secondary neuropathy?

Excellent! The last secondary outcome measure I would suggest is the duration of transfusion-free remission. This measure assesses the duration of time without transfusions in patients who do not exhibit any signs of breakthrough hemolysis. It will provide insight into the duration of transfusion-free remission in patients receiving the combination therapy. Do you agree with including this measure?

Excellent choice! With so many measures to choose from, how do we decide which ones to use in our clinical practice? And how often should we monitor these measures? It can often be overwhelming to choose which measures to track in a patient's care pathway. There are several ways to approach measurement and there is not a single, definitive answer. However, following these suggestions can help you in making this critical decision: Choose measures that align with your clinical practice pattern and patient population. For example, for elderly patients, QOL and physical function may be priorities than functional exercise capacity. Choose measures that are clinically meaningful and meaningful to your patients. This may involve discussions with frontline staff and patients. Make sure the measures are feasible in your setting. Make sure there is a defined approach to measuring the measures and how and when to report results. Include a plan to address treatment non-adherence or comorbidities that may impact outcomes. Most importantly, ensure appropriate follow-up and management based on the measured results. With many new measures available in practice, it is important to continuously evaluate and refine the measure set based on the collected data. In summary, measuring the right set of endpoints is essential to guide your patient-centered treatment decision-making. To get insights from industry experts on how to measure healthcare performance, stay tuned for our next Measuring What Matters blog, where we will explore the art and science of measuring quality metrics in hemophilia care. About the Contributor Debraj Misra, MD, MMM, MBA, FACP, is the Medical Director for Amgen's Bleeding and Coagulation Therapeutic Area and President of the Bleeding and Coagulation Network Management Board at Amgen. Dr. Misra is an Associate Professor of Medicine at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. A graduate of the Ohio State University College of Medicine and a hematologist/medical oncologist, Dr. Misra has devoted his career to studying and treating bleeding and clotting disorders. In addition to his clinical work with patients, Dr. Misra has conducted numerous clinical and quality improvement research studies evaluating the quality, cost, and outcomes of care for patients with bleeding and clotting disorders.

That's a great summary of the key outcome measures for our clinical trial. With the parameters agreed upon, we are ready to draft the outcomes section of our protocol.
The outcomes section should include the main objectives of the trial, along with clear, concise, and measurable aims for each. It should also specify the intended use of the data collected, the primary and secondary outcomes, and the specific patient population being studied. CERD recommends using the Plain English System, developed by the ICMJE (International Committee of Medical Journal Editors,) to express the main outcome measures. This system uses three-to-five key words, including a verb, to clearly summarize each outcome.
The ICMJE recommends using the following wording for each outcome: "mortality, disability, quality of life, symptom relief/control, functional ability, and sign and symptom abnormalities."1 However, the use of these key words is not mandatory. The key is to be clear and concise and to choose the most appropriate outcome measures for the study. The CERD also recommends avoiding the use of surrogate endpoints such as surrogate markers of disease progression. These include blood pressure and heart rate as markers of hypertension and cardiac function. Surrogate endpoints can be misleading, especially in stroke trials where there is no accepted endpoint. In stroke, functional independence is a better outcome measure than mobility or muscle strength. The Clinical Trials Transformation Initiative offers many helpful resources and checklists for developing an outcomes page, including a sample outcomes section from a stroke clinical trial protocol.
In addition to the outcomes page, the CERD recommends including a sample case report form (CRF) for each of the study's outcomes. These forms will allow investigators to clearly specify and define each measure before the trial begins. The CERD also recommends including a plan for how the data will be managed and analyzed, along with details on how the safety reporting will be organized. It is crucial to provide detailed planning in this section to avoid confusion and duplication of work during the trial.
Once the protocol is complete, the CERD recommends submitting it for independent review by a peer-reviewed journal or by an academic/industry collaborator, and obtaining feedback before finalizing the document

Human Subjects Protection The IRB may request amendments to a research study during the conduct of a study. Examples of reasons to amend a research study include: ❑ a change in subject population ❑ a change in research plan, data analysis, or data collection instruments ❑ unexpected human subjects issues ❑ unanticipated problems ❑ revisions to address a reviewers’ comments ❑ changes in staff listed in the approved protocol ❑ need to secure continuing review prior to expiration of approval term ❑ termination of funding ❑ concerns raised by sponsor or institution ❑ changes needed to conform with sponsor instructions ❑ a need to discontinue participation by an IRB member ❑ changes in investigators or institution staff who will be involved in the study. All proposed amendments to approved research studies must be submitted on the appropriate form and meet the criteria of an IRB "minor" or "major" alteration as determined by the IRB. The Investigator must submit an IRB form "Change in Investigator" if there is a change in the PI. If the IRB deems a submission as a major study alteration, they will be forwarded to the convened IRB meeting for review. Notification of IRB Approval and IRB Continuing Oversight Recommendations Once the research has received IRB approval, the investigator must notify the IRB in writing of the study's approval and the date the approval begins. Research projects that are subject to IRB review must receive ongoing oversight by the IRB committee. The investigator must submit study progress reports and any protocol amendments to the IRB on the schedule specified by the IRB, and promptly submit any protocol amendments that are necessary. model_response: The Q-LES-Q is another great measure to assess quality of life in clinical trials. You're right, it would provide valuable information about the impact of tDCS on overall well-being beyond symptoms alone. In addition, I also recommend assessing adverse effects using the Clinician-Administered PTSD Screen for Dsm 5 (CAPS-5). This measure is commonly used in studies assessing the efficacy of tDCS for PTSD symptoms, and it can help capture any potential negative side effects from the procedure. I think incorporating these measures would provide a comprehensive picture of the effectiveness of tDCS for depression.

Assessing cognitive function is crucial to determine the safety and effectiveness of tDCS. A battery of neuropsychological tests will provide a comprehensive evaluation of cognitive abilities such as memory, concentration, and processing speed. Comparing the changes in cognitive function between the sham and active tDCS groups will shed light on whether tDCS improves cognitive abilities or not. I recommend baseline testing prior to the intervention to establish a benchmark for any changes in cognitive function over time. This will ensure the reliability of the testing methods and results.

Yes, monitoring adverse events is critical for ensuring the safety of study participants. Assessing the occurrence of adverse events will provide important information on the safety profile of the intervention. Comparing the rates of adverse events between the two groups would provide useful information on the safety profile of tDCS treatment. I agree that keeping the time frame for adverse events consistent with the other outcomes makes sense. Here are our summary measures: Primary outcome measure #1: Assessment of system accuracy at Day 1 (measured value/true value) by DIN EN ISO 15197 Secondary outcome measure #1: Test-retest reliability/agreement on Day 1 (Measured value /Measured value) The blood glucose monitor is a small, portable device that measures and displays glucose levels in the blood. It relies on a sample of blood obtained from the finger or other site on the body by a small needle or sensor and is widely used by people with diabetes for monitoring their glucose control. The glucose values reported by the monitor are used to adjust insulin dosages or to adjust the exogenous glucose infusion if performing an artificial pancreas closed-loop protocol. Since the first introduction of blood glucose monitoring tools, they have undergone incremental updates, some of which have brought with them substantial improvements in clinical usefulness. Each new iteration of blood glucose meters offers improved accuracy compared with previous generations. The current "state of the art" of blood glucose monitors now is represented by meters with "built-in" algorithms that measure the blood glucose level and report it in the form of a number between 0 and 120 mg/dL. The measurement principle uses a test strip that contains a small amount of glucose that is metabolized by an enzyme (usually glucose oxidase, or glucose hexokinase in some cases) that covers the surface of the test strip. Glucose metabolism by the enzyme releases electrons that are used in a chain of reactions that generate a small electrical current that can be measured at the opposite end of the strip. The specifics of the assay are different between different meters but the principles are essentially the same. The main thing that changes is the quality and precision of the enzyme, of the reference electrode system with the glucose solution with which the meter calibrates itself, and of the software that processes the meter's output data. model_response: Certainly. The EDSS ranges from 0-10, with 0 being no disability and 10 being death. It includes 8 components: neurological signs, brain MRI, spinal cord MRI, eye evaluation, cerebellar ataxia, and bladder function. I also have a list of other measures you may want to consider assessing. How's that sound?

I think it is helpful to assess functional ability as well. One measure that can be used for this is the Timed 25-Foot Walk. It's a timed walk from the start line to a fixed point 25 feet away. How much time is allowed for the walk? Is there a cutoff time that you recommend?

The MSIS-29 consists of two parts, the physical symptom and the MSIS-29 PCS short form. The physical symptom section includes 27 items, while the PCS short form has 20 items. The physical symptom scale and PCS short form are combined to form the overall MSIS-29 score, which is a measure of disease severity. Higher scores represent a greater level of disability. This measure is considered sensitive and responsive to change over time. This questionnaire has been validated across multiple cultural and ethnic groups. It is widely used in clinical trials and also used by individuals with MS to track disease progression. Another important measure is the Timed 25-foot Walk Test. Would you like to include this measure too?
Among other measures, we could also assess the amount of fatigue using the Multiple Sclerosis Fatigue Questionnaire (MSFQ). What would you like to do with respect to fatigue measures?

The SF-36 has two versions, the SF-36 Health Survey and the SF-36 Mental Health Survey. Each measures 36 items. Scores range from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating better health status. What other measures would you like to include for assessing effectiveness of the intervention?

Since the intervention you hope to evaluate is blood flow-restricted exercise, it may be helpful to assess aerobic capacity by exercise stress testing. Would you like to include measures of aerobic capacity in your trial?

Yes. The MVIC test measures the maximal isometric force of a person's muscle. In the MVIC test, the participant sits or lies on a dynamometer while their knees are supported. They are then asked to contract their muscles against the dynamometer with maximum effort until they cannot continue. The measurement is expressed in units of force in relation to body weight. The Sit to Stand test measures muscle strength in a seated position. In this test, the person sits on the floor with legs straight out in front of them. The examiner asks them to rise to a standing position without using their arms. The test is timed, and the time in seconds is recorded. People with greater muscle strength have a lower sit to stand time. Is there anything else you'd like to include in our list of primary measures?

Nutritional status is an important consideration in disease-modifying treatment trials. We can measure body mass index (BMI), skin fold thickness, and/or blood chemistry to assess nutritional status. Would you like to assess them in your participants? ❋ Yes ❎ No ❌ Are there any other primary outcome measures you would like to recommend?

The T25FWT measures the time required to walk 25 feet in a heel strike pattern at a normal speed without stopping or leaning on the arms. Increased time indicates reduced gait efficiency, which may result from gait impact. This test provides valuable information on neuromuscular fatigue, balance, and coordination. How many weeks would you like to measure gait impact?

There are several other important measures that we can also include to determine progress during the course of the study. These include assessments of the timed 25-foot walk and 6-minute walk (measuring the distance we can walk in 6 minutes), 12-minute walk (measuring the distance we can walk in 12 minutes), Stair Climb Test (measures the number of flights of stairs that can be climbed in 6 minutes), and the 12-week trunk circumference measurement. These measures provide insight into respiratory function, upper extremity function, and cardiorespiratory fitness. Would you like to include these measures in our study?

The HADS is a questionnaire consisting of 14 statements that assess anxiety and depression levels on a 4-point Likert-type scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much). Total scores greater than 16 indicate a high level of anxiety and total scores greater than 15 indicate a high level of depression. The HADS can be administered in just 5 to 10 minutes. How long would you like us to assess anxiety and depression using the HADS?
Sleep quality is important to assess as well. We can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) for this. Would you like to include it in the study?
The PSQI is a questionnaire of 19 questions that measures sleep quality on a scale of 0 to 28. Higher scores indicate poor sleep quality. How long would you like to track sleep quality?
Pain symptoms are also important to assess. We can use the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) for this purpose. Would you like to include this measure?

The 10-MWT assesses the participant's walking speed over 10 meters. The person walks as quickly and independently as possible and the time is recorded. The test is considered failed if the person cannot complete the test in 10 seconds. Poor walking speed is indicated by a slow time. The TUG test assesses the rate at which a person can rise from a seated position, walk a short distance, turn around and return to a seated position. The time is recorded and poor walk speed is indicated by a time greater than 14 seconds. Are there any other outcome measures you would like us to consider?
Balance is another key factor to assess. We can use the Berg Balance Profile (BBP) to measure static and dynamic balance. Would you like to include the BBP as a primary measure?

The GLTEQ is a self-reported measure of physical fitness and exercise capacity. It consists of 10 items regarding exercise frequency, intensity, enjoyment, and energy expended. Higher scores indicate greater levels of physical fitness and exercise. How long would you like to assess physical fitness using the GLTEQ?
We can also include the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) to assess physical activity. Do you have any other questions or preferences?

Sure. The 6-MWT is a simple, non-invasive test that assesses exercise capacity. Participants are asked to walk as far as they can in a certain area in 6 minutes. The shorter the distance covered, the lower the exercise capacity. How long would you like to measure walking endurance using the 6-MWT?

Balance and fear of falling are also important to assess. We can employ the Timed Up and Go (TUG) Test for balance and the Berg Balance Scale for fear of falling. Would you like to include these measures?

The anxiety subscales uses words and phrases such as: restlessness, nervousness, fatigue, and apprehension, while the depression subscales uses words and phrases such as low self-esteem, low interest, and depressed affect. model_response: Secondary outcome measures typically focus on evaluating long-term effectiveness and functional abnormalities. For this trial, we can measure quality of life using standard questionnaires such as the EORTC Quality of Life Questionnaire (QLQ-C30) and the EuroQol-visual analog scale (EQ-VAS). These questionnaires evaluate health-related quality of life from multiple perspectives, such as physical and emotional functioning, social support, and well-being. Additionally, we could also measure the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-General (FACT-G). Lastly, we could measure physical functioning and symptoms using the European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Module for Solid Tumor patients (EORTC QLQ-MTX35). This module includes measures of symptoms such as pain, fatigue, dyspnea, appetite, and bowel/bladder functioning. These outcome measures will help us understand the long-term impact of this novel treatment on the patients' well-being and ability to perform daily activities.

I think it makes sense to monitor PRO-CTCAE from the start of treatment through the end of treatment. This will allow us to track the impact of the intervention on patient-reported side effects over time. Is there any other information you would like to add?

To further evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment, we could include measures of quality of life, symptom burden, and long-term safety. One such measure that is commonly used in palliative care is the EORTC QLQ-C30 + QLQ-PAL questionnaire. This is a standardized self-report questionnaire that assesses functional impairment, disease control, and emotional well-being in palliative patients with cancer. Other measures we may consider are the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) Questionnaire and the European Organisation for the Research and Treatment of Cancer QOL Measure Questionnaire (EORTC QOL). Do you have any other suggestions for outcome measures?

Yes, we can specify a time frame of 0-30 days, 31-90 days, and 91+ days. This will allow us to evaluate changes in quality of life before and after the treatment. Are there any other outcome measures you would recommend?

Definitely! I would also suggest monitoring the patient's tumor status. We should use imaging or other methods to assess the response to treatment at specific time points, such as one month, three months and six months after treatment starts and again at the end of radiotherapy. What do you think?
Are there any other measures we should consider?

model_response: The RCL assay evaluates the production of replication capable lentiviral particles from the production process. The number of infectious units is measured at baseline, Day 7, and Day 9 of the manufacturing cycle. Production of RCL ensures that the therapy can infect the patient's CSCs and produce an anti-tumor effect.

The Development of anti-drug antibodies (ADA) measure the production of antibodies against the therapy. This is an important measure to ensure the quality of the therapy. The time frame for monitoring ADA is up to 6 months from LPI.

The secondary outcome measures include Clinical response, which refers to the reduction of tumor size or other measurable abnormalities. The time frame for monitoring Clinical response is up to 6 months from LPI. Other secondary outcome measures include End of treatment Evaluation of Immunogenicity, Genotypic Analysis to identify potential variants or modifications of the EU307 product, Adverse Events (SAEs or AEs) and Immunogenicity. These measures are used to assess the safety and efficacy of the therapy. What do you think? Are these measures adequate for the clinical trial of a novel gene therapy like EU307? Or do they need to be modified?

Sure, Objective Response Rate (ORR) is a measure of the proportion of patients who experience a partial or complete response to the IP during the therapy. Duration of Response (DoR) is the duration of time during which a patient experiences a partial or complete response to the therapy. Disease Control Rate (DCR) is calculated by dividing the number of patients with a PR or CR by the number of patients who experience either disease progression or death during the therapy. Time to Response (TTR) is the time from the start of therapy to the first objective response. Time to Progression (TTP) is the time from therapy initiation to the first evidence of disease progression. Progression-Free Survival (PFS) is the time from therapy initiation to disease progression or death. Overall Survival (OS) is the time from therapy initiation to death from any cause. These measures are important to monitor the impact of the IP on disease progression and overall survival.

The Duration of Response (DoR) is a different way of measuring the extent of response to the treatment. It refers to the time from the first documented response (CR or PR) to disease progression or death. It helps us understand the durability of the initial response. The time frame for evaluating DoR is up to 6 months.
The Disease Control Rate (DCR) measures the proportion of subjects with a confirmed response. The time frame for evaluating DCR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Response (TTR) measures time to CR or PR from the first dose of therapy. It provides information on the speed of response to the therapy. The time frame for evaluating TTR is up to 6 months.

The Time to Progression (TTP) measures the time from IP dosing to confirmed disease progression. It helps evaluate the therapy's ability to control disease progression. The time frame for evaluating TTP is up to 6 months.

The Progression-Free Survival (PFS) measures the time from the initiation of IP dosing to disease progression or death due to any cause. It measures the duration of disease control. The time frame for evaluating PFS is up to 6 months.

The Overall Survival (OS) measures the time from study entry to all-cause death. It provides information on overall survival of the entire study population. The time frame for evaluating OS is indefinitely.

I agree with you that the secondary outcome measures you suggested will produce a more fulsome picture of the treatment's effectiveness. Let's continue with the statistical analysis plan. Do you plan to use both a between-group and within-group analysis?

Secondly, positive affect would be measured using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) over a time frame of pre-intervention (T1), post-intervention (T2). The PANAS is a widely used tool to quantify subjective feelings of affect. It measures positive and negative affect separately. Negative affect is distinguished as the opposite of pleasurable experience. Positive affect is more accurately defined as the overall frequency of pleasant/unpleasant emotions. This measure is considered a useful tool to gauge mental well-being. Furthermore, negative affect is more precisely determined by the experience of unpleasant sensations of the body. Time frame: 1 year Since this measure is a survival endpoint, it is measured from the time of randomization. Do you have any other primary outcome measures you would like to include?

Yes, the secondary outcome measures you suggest will be very useful in assessing the success of the surgical intervention and disease control, as well as overall survival. Well, to further assess disease control and survival, I would suggest including measures such as the 1-year event-free survival rate, disease-free survival rate, and overall survival rate. These measures provide a snapshot of the patient's overall disease progression and clinical outcomes. To monitor the time frame, I would use up to 3 years. 1-year event-free survival rate: The proportion of patients who have not experienced an event (recurrence, progression, or treatment-related mortality) by one year after treatment. For each patient who has not experienced an event, it represents the proportion of that patient population alive and free of events at one year, or equivalent survival time. Disease-free survival rate: The proportion of patients who are alive and free of progression or recurrence at a specific time interval after treatment initiation. It represents the proportion of patients having no evidence of progression or recurrence, whether or not they are still alive, at a specific time point. Overall survival rate: The proportion of patients who survive a specific time interval after treatment initiation. 1-year event-free survival rate: The proportion of patients who are alive and disease-free at one year. 1-year event-free survival rate: Percent = 100 × (number of patients not having experienced an event)/ number of patients with events One must know the exact types of event(s) of interest. Disease-free survival rate: Percent = 100 × (number of patients not having experienced progression or recurrence)/ number of patients with progression or recurrences. Overall survival rate: Percent = 100 × (number of patients who are alive and not experiencing either event or progression or recurrence) / (number of patients with any events + number of patients with progression or recurrences). These measures can provide essential information on the efficacy of the current treatment and helps to guide future study design and direction. model_response: This measure will determine the proportion of eligible patients who drop out from the study before the final follow-up. It will help assess the acceptability of the physiotherapy intervention. The time frame for this measure is from baseline to one-year follow-up.

This measure will help appraise the intervention's impact on quality of life. Patients will be asked to fill out a survey at baseline and at one and 16 weeks after initiating the intervention. A response rate of more than 80% at both time points would suggest a well-accepted and tolerated intervention.

The "Adverse events" measure is essential for the safety monitoring of the trial participants. It aims to assess the occurrence of any unintended or undesirable side effects of the intervention among the trial participants. Assessing adverse events would help determine the safety and tolerability of the intervention and modify the protocol or treatment if necessary. The time frame for this measure is throughout the duration of the study. This sounds like a great list of outcome measures. And that's great news for us as the burden of proof is on you, the sponsor, to show that the intervention is safe and effective for the intended purpose!

The remaining outcome measures are all secondary. They will help to quantify the effect of the intervention on the patient population at 12 and 24 weeks. The "Deep venous thrombosis progression" measure will assess the progression of the initial DVT while the remaining measures will assess the effectiveness of the intervention in preventing post-thrombotic syndrome.

Compliance to the training program: This measure will assess the extent to which the participants adhere to the recommended physiotherapy training program. We can evaluate this through telephone calls, observation, or by reviewing the physical activity logs kept by the patients. Change in physical activity level: This measure will assess the quantity and quality of physical activity before and after the intervention. Satisfaction with the intervention: This measure will evaluate the patient's satisfaction with the physiotherapy intervention. It will help us identify any areas where we need to improve our intervention. Change in quality of life: This measure will evaluate the improvement in the patient's health-related quality of life before and after the intervention.

For this measure, I would use the Godin Leisure-time Physical Activity Questionnaire, which assesses exercise behavior during leisure time. The measure includes questionnaires administered at baseline and at one month after the intervention. A favorable change in exercise level of more than 30 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity on most or all days of the week would suggest that the intervention is effective in promoting physical activity. The time frame for this measure is from baseline to one month.

Satisfaction with the intervention is an important measure to assess the acceptability and satisfaction with the intervention among patients. This measure is self-reported and aims to determine participant satisfaction with the intervention. The time frame for this measure is from baseline to one month.

The last measure I would recommend is "Change in quality of life" which aims to evaluate the change in quality of life from baseline to one month based on the Nottingham Health Profile Questionnaire. This measure will provide data on the intervention's impact on the patients' quality of life. The time frame for this measure is also one month.  Thanks for your recommendations.
